Media: The New York Times
Review: This big but tentative show doesn<U+2019>t burst with flavor of any kind, not during its exposition-crammed first act. Only in its second half does the show acquire a distinct taste and it isn<U+2019>t confectionary...The idea of macabre punishment seems to have acted as a stimulant on the creative faculties of everyone involved as the show turns increasingly surreal...Most gratifying is the transformation of Borle...Willy switches into dissing diva mode with a skip in his step and a fork in his tongue.

Media: Theatermania
Review: Incorporating songs from the film, it seems to present itself as earnest entertainment for children and nostalgic adults. Grieg's caustic book and Shaiman and Wittman's pastiche score, on the other hand, feels like a beast with much sharper talons...The show gets considerably better in the second act, when it becomes the Christian Borle show. He exudes a manic genius that fits the eccentric candy industrialist...He can't save everything though...A musical that doesn't know what it wants to be.

Media: Time Out New York
Review: Joyless, shapeless and grating...a stale Necco wafer of a musical...O<U+2019>Brien directs this dull, clunky adaptation of the book and movie with none of the wit of the former nor the dreamy wonder of the latter. Maybe kids will enjoy the gaudy design and veneer of sassy satire, but when you bite down, there<U+2019>s only empty shell. Younger audiences can cheer, but adults are bound to conclude that 'Charlie' is like what happens with an Everlasting Gobstopper: lots of sucking.

Media: Variety
Review: The uncanny darkness of Dahl<U+2019>s imagination has been lightened and brightened in helmer Jack O<U+2019>Brien<U+2019>s mechanized production...While visually droll, too many of the gimmicks distract from the story and encourage the cartoon treatment of characters as caricatures. Happily, the character of Charlie Bucket escapes this mishandling...Ryan Foust was the best thing in the show...As played by Borle, Willy Wonka's much too charming and lacks the aura of stranger-danger.

Media: Lighting & Sound America
Review: If it is hardly the best musical on Broadway, it is surely the most improved...The book suffers from the fact that it takes an entire act to get to the chocolate factory...The second act is, quite possibly, the most macabre children's entertainment ever...If 'Charlie' isn't likely to entertain adults looking for a sophisticated Broadway musical, it is probably just the thing for parents looking to take the kids to a show. They aren't likely to notice its less-than-seamless assembly.

Media: New York Theater
Review: <U+201C>The overall effect manages to be too obvious and yet too bland...I have nothing especially negative to say about most of the performances, including Borle<U+2019>s, although nothing especially positive to say about the actors portraying the four insufferable children who won the sought-after golden tickets<U+2026>Their ends are clearly meant to be clever, but don<U+2019>t sparkle in the execution<U+2026>I suspect there are enough moments to make the show at least intermittently enjoyable for adult chaperones.<U+201D>

Media: Theater Life
Review: <U+201C>Neither relevant nor even consistently entertaining, but it does provide the occasional guilty-pleasure shot of sweetness...Unfortunately these are few and far between<U+2026>This uneven kiddie show takes us on a roller-coaster ride with too many flat stretches<U+2026>The old tunes remain sources of delight as do a handful of the newer ones. But David Greig<U+2019>s book misses the strong narrative drive of the original and the cinema versions.<U+201D>

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: It's just bad: plain, simple, and totally. Although, to be fair, it does keep one-upping itself<U+2014>this is not a musical that's willing to settle for second-worst...Should have been a slam-dunk property...This show rebukes all of that potential, as well as stamping out the material's warmth and charm...As for Shaiman and Wittman's score, it's shallow and tacky, by leagues the pair's weakest work for Broadway...A massive, melty mess.

Media: Broadway Blog
Review: <U+201C>Although not a fan of Dahl's high-calorie story even I found some of it satisfying and delicious<U+2026>While no show could compete with Hollywood's special effects, there's plenty of cleverness displayed in the gimmicky scenery<U+2026>and ingenious staging. The child-unfriendly ways that punish the plot's entitled brats are a hoot, and even queasy stomachs will likely ingest such comic images as people bursting into purple goop or dismembered by squirrels.<U+201D>

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: <U+201C>There<U+2019>s enough on-stage pizzazz to keep the pre-teens charged and cheering...I have to report that the sweets dispensed here have no appeal for me...The primary problem is with Greig<U+2019>s prolific book, which, among other things, is all over the place...In regards to humor, of which <U+2018>Charlie and the Chocolate Factory<U+2019> is totally devoid: book writer Greig is unable to land a single joke...Given the wafer-thin meager material, the cast members are pretty much left to fend for themselves.<U+201D>

Media: AM New York
Review: Disastrous and distasteful...An ultra-aggressive, play-it-up silliness pervades every aspect of the show, turning what is a tender and fanciful story into a loud and brash frenzy...There is a desperate quality to Borle<U+2019>s upbeat performance. Media: The Hollywood Reporter
Review: The perversely charmless new musical will have little to offer grown-up audiences. Media: New York Magazine / Vulture
Review: A show like 'Charlie' ought to have been a treat...So why did the thing turn into a hideous, cheap-looking, melted Whitman<U+2019>s sampler  The glib answer is: too many cooks...The longer answer begins with Dahl. Media: New York Daily News
Review: The candy man can<U+2019>t. Media: Times Square Chronicles
Review: The set by Mark Thompson doesn<U+2019>t wow, the music by Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman misses the mark...I am a huge Christian Borle fan and, though it pains me to say it, Borle, in wonderful voice, is not the Willy Wonka from the book or the movies. Media: Deadline
Review: It<U+2019>s goofy, loud and imaginative<U+2014>superlatively so...It<U+2019>s not as theatrically inventive as 'Matilda,' and it probably won<U+2019>t share that show<U+2019>s canny ability to appeal to adults as well as kids...The supporting cast does well by the Shaiman and Wittman numbers, which fill out the characters with considerable humor...The moments of pleasure for this adult viewer were decidedly scattershot...Grown-ups will serve their purpose as ticket buyers, and their tykes will get the sugar rush.

Media: Theater In The Now
Review: This musical confection spins a flavor that can only be described as modern...If you're looking to throw your cares away and just have fun, there's nothing more tantalizing...But if a well-structured, smartly planned musical is what you seek, this show swings for the fences and strikes out often...The new music is vibrant, modern, and earworm-worthy...The libretto was overstuffed...This show was all about the visuals, treading the fine line of homage and originality.

Media: Chicago Tribune
Review: A deeply disappointing musical...You do get flashes of Dahl's brand of caustic fun. For a few seconds. Media: Newsday
Review: For a musical about the wonder of pure imagination, 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' is bizarrely lacking in it...It<U+2019>s almost painful to watch Borle, a master of endearing virtuosity, work so hard to sell charm that simply isn<U+2019>t in the script, the music and too much of the staging...The show is saccharine and soporific. Media: The Wrap

Media: Front Mezz Junkies
Review: This musical is as sweet and charming as can be, with a gleefully dose of wickedness that isn<U+2019>t too dark or deadly...The production whistles along quite competently hitting all the right notes of wonder, sweetness, and more importantly, devilishness when the recipe starts feeling a bit too sweet...I can<U+2019>t say this musical is a revelation in any way, and at times the story lacked a strong drive forward...I was never bored, but I can<U+2019>t say I was fully engaged with my heart or my soul.

Media: WNBC
Review: More often than it should, 'Charlie' fails children when trying to speak to adults, and vice versa...An inability to hit the right tone and sustain it is a serious problem...The music is a combination of other songs from the film and mostly bland new work by Marc Shaiman and Scott Wittman...For all its attempts to recreate the delight of Roald Dahl<U+2019>s story, it left me with something of a toothache.

Media: Theater Pizzazz

Media: The Washington Post
Review: 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' imagines itself cleverly subversive, but it<U+2019>s just a shrill and nasty cartoon. Media: Towleroad

Media: Out Magazine
Review: 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory' wants very badly to be loved. Media: DC Metro Theater Arts
Review: <U+201C>I found this musical version oddly sweet and gooey, but David Greig<U+2019>s book I found more Dull than Dahl. As a result, despite star Christian Borle<U+2019>s game effort to inject charm into the characters of Willie Wonka and the <U+2018>Candy Man,<U+2019> the long first act didn<U+2019>t offer me much to cheer about<U+2026>The second act improves noticeably for Mr. Borle comes into his own and the Oompa Loompas arrive.<U+201D>

Media: CurtainUp
Review: Borle plays Wonka with exhilarating ferocity. Abetted by a compellingly motivated company...Some transfers from film or book to stage work and some don't. Media: Musical Theater Review

Media: Epoch Times
Review: <U+201C>Sadly, the show fails to keep faith with its source material, proving to be an uneven mixture of satire and wistfulness<U+2026>The show<U+2019>s creators aren<U+2019>t sure whether to present a childhood fantasy or a dark allegory...The musical numbers written especially for the stage are not nearly as strong as the tunes used in the film<U+2026>But Borle does an excellent job...<U+2018>Charlie<U+2019> reminds one of a rather misshapen cake. Media: The Stage (UK)

Media: BroadwaySelect
